name: Marfan Syndrome
description: Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the body's connective tissue, which provides support and structure to organs and tissues throughout the body. It primarily affects the heart, blood vessels, bones, joints, and eyes.
ageOfOnset: Can be present from birth, often diagnosed in childhood or adolescence
symptoms: Tall, slender build with long limbs
Chest that curves inward or outward
prognosis: With proper management, individuals can have a normal or near-normal life expectancy
lifeExpectancy: 70+ years with proper treatment (historically 40-50 years without treatment)
diagnosticMethods: MRI or CT scan of the aorta
eli5Summary: Marfan syndrome is like having a body where the 'glue' that holds everything together isn't as strong as it should be. This makes people grow tall with long arms and fingers, and it can affect the heart and eyes. Doctors can help manage it with medicines and sometimes surgery.
clinicalSummary: Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in the FBN1 gene encoding fibrillin-1. Cardinal features include cardiovascular manifestations (aortic root dilatation, mitral valve prolapse), skeletal abnormalities (dolichostenomelia, arachnodactyly, pectus deformities), and ocular findings (ectopia lentis, myopia). Diagnosis is based on the revised Ghent nosology. Management focuses on beta-blocker or ARB therapy for aortic protection and prophylactic aortic root surgery when indicated.
historicalBackground: The syndrome was first described by French pediatrician Antoine Marfan in 1896 when he noticed unusually long limbs in a 5-year-old girl named Gabrielle. The genetic basis was discovered in 1991 when mutations in the FBN1 gene were identified. The understanding of the condition has evolved significantly, with the role of TGF-β dysregulation being discovered in the 2000s, leading to the use of losartan as a treatment.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Gene therapy trials show promise
recentBreakthroughs.description: Early-phase clinical trials testing CRISPR-based approaches to correct FBN1 mutations have shown encouraging safety profiles.

recentBreakthroughs.title: AI-powered aortic monitoring
recentBreakthroughs.description: Machine learning algorithms can now predict aortic dissection risk with 95% accuracy using echocardiogram data.

recentBreakthroughs.title: New biomarkers identified
recentBreakthroughs.description: Circulating TGF-β levels validated as predictive biomarkers for disease progression.
